sen.j: 文武天皇（もんむてんのう、天武天皇11年（683年） - 慶雲4年6月15日 (旧暦)（707年7月18日））は、日本の第42代天皇（在位：文武天皇元年8月17日 (旧暦)（697年9月7日） - 慶雲4年6月15日 (旧暦)（707年7月18日））。
sen.e: Emperor Monmu (683 - July 18, 707) was the forty-second Emperor.(his reign lasted from September 7, 697 to July 18, 707).
Emperor Monmu (683 - July 18, 707) was the forty-second Emperor (who reigned from September 7, 697, to July 18, 707).
sen.cmt: スペーシング、パンクチュエーション、用語
sen.e: Emperor Monmu (683 - July 18, 707) was the forty-second Emperor (who reigned from September 7, 697, to July 18, 707).
His first name was Karu.
sen.cmt: 嵯峨天皇の中で、名は神野（かみの）は、His first name was Kamino.になっていますが、宇多天皇の中では、名は定省（さだみ）はThe last name is Sadami.になっています。名は恐らく first name だと思いますので、first としました。
sen.e: He was born Prince Karu which was written as either "珂瑠" or "軽" in Kanji.
sen.cmt: 表現。漢字表記にまで言及。
sen.e: He was born Prince Karu which was written as either "珂瑠" or "軽" in Kanji.

sen.j: 和風諡号は2つあり、『続日本紀』の707年（慶雲4年11月12日）に「倭根子豊祖父天皇」と、『続日本紀』797年（延暦16年）に諡された「天之眞宗豊祖父天皇」（あめのまむねとよおほぢのすめらみこと）がある。
sen.e: He had two Japanese-style posthumous names; one was Emperor "Yamato neko Toyo-ohji no Sumeramikoto" in "Shoku Nihongi"(Chronicle of Japan Continued) of 707 and "Ama mo Mamune Toyo-ohoji no Sumeramikoto" in "Shoku Nihongi" of 797.
sen.cmt: 倭根子豊祖父天皇 やまとねことよおほじのすめらみこと続日本紀 "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued)
sen.e: He had two Japanese-style posthumous names: 'Yamato neko toyo oji no sumeramikoto' (the term 'yamato' means Japan and 'sumeramikoto' an emperor) appearing in an entry from "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicles of Japan Continued) dated the year 707 and 'Ama mo mamune toyo oji no sumeramikoto' in an entry from the "Shoku Nihongi" dated the year 797.
sen.cmt: スペーシング、引用符、表現、書名。続日本紀英語表記参考：http://eos.kokugakuin.ac.jp/modules/xwords/entry.php?entryID=1269
sen.e: He had two Japanese-style posthumous names: 'Yamato neko toyo oji no sumeramikoto' (the term 'yamato' means Japan and 'sumeramikoto' an emperor) appearing in an entry from "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicles of Japan Continued) dated the year 707 and 'Ama mo mamune toyo oji no sumeramikoto' in an entry from the "Shoku Nihongi" dated the year 797.

sen.j: 草壁皇子（天武天皇第二皇子）の長子。
sen.e: He was the firstborn child of Prince Kusakabe no miko. (second prince of Emperor Tenmu)
He was the firstborn child of Prince Kusakabe no miko (the second son of Emperor Tenmu).
sen.cmt: スペーシング、パンクチュエーション
sen.e: He was the firstborn child of Prince Kusakabe no miko (the second son of Emperor Tenmu).

sen.j: 母は阿陪皇女（元明天皇）。
sen.e: His mother was Princess Ahe. (Empress Genmei)
His mother was Princess Ahe no himemiko (Empress Genmei).
sen.cmt: パンクチュエーション、補足
sen.e: His mother was Princess Ahe no himemiko (Empress Genmei).

sen.j: 父草壁は皇太子位のまま亡くなり即位していないため、本来であれば「皇子」ではなく「王」の呼称が用いられるはずだが、祖母である持統天皇の後見もあってか、立太子以前から皇子の扱いを受けていたと思われる。
sen.e: His father had died as a prince and was not enthroned so normally, he would be addressed "王" (king) rather than "皇子" (prince), but it may have been for Emperor Jito's guardianship, he was treated as a prince before he became the crown prince.

Since his father, Kusakabe, had died as crown prince before enthronement, Karu should have normally been addressed "王" (referring to male imperial family members) rather than "皇子" (referring to emperor's legitimate sons or emperor's blood brothers), but it may have been due to his grandmother Empress Jito's guardianship that he had supposedly been treated as the latter before he truly became the crown prince.

Since his father, Kusakabe, had died as crown prince before enthronement, Karu should have normally been addressed "王" (referring to male imperial family members) rather than "皇子" (referring to emperor's legitimate sons or emperor's blood brothers), but it may have been due to his grandmother Empress Jito's guardianship that he had supposedly been treated as the latter before he truly became the crown prince.

sen.j: 父草壁が689年に亡くなり、696年には伯父にあたる高市皇子も薨じたため、697年2月立太子。
sen.e: His father Kusakabe died in 689 and his uncle, PrinceTakechi (Takechi no Miko) also died in 696 so he became the Crown Prince in February 697.
His father, Prince Kusakabe, died in 689 and his uncle, PrinceTakechi (Takechi no miko), also died in 696, and therefore Karu became the Crown Prince in February, 697.
sen.cmt: so he became→and therefore Karu became
sen.e: His father, Prince Kusakabe, died in 689 and his uncle, PrinceTakechi (Takechi no miko), also died in 696, and therefore Karu became the Crown Prince in February, 697.

sen.j: 同年8月、祖母・持統天皇に譲位され即位した。
sen.e: In August of the year described above, he succeeded to the Imperial Throne after his grandmother, Empress Jito, passed the position to him.
In August of the same year (697), his grandmother, Empress Jito, decided to pass the emperorship to him, and Karu thus became Emperor Monmu.
In August of the same year (697), his grandmother, Empress Jito, decided to pass the emperorship to him, and Karu thus became Emperor Monmu.

sen.j: 当時15歳という若さであったため、持統が上皇として後見役についた。
sen.e: Since he was 15-years-old, a considerably young age, Jito took the position of the Retired Empress as his guardian.
Since he was only 15 years old at his enthronement ceremony, Jito resumed power as the Retired Empress to guard the young emperor.
Since he was only 15 years old at his enthronement ceremony, Jito resumed power as the Retired Empress to guard the young emperor.

sen.j: 701年（大宝(日本)元年）に大宝律令が完成し、翌年公布している。
sen.e: The Taiho Code was completed in 701 and officially proclaimed in the following year.
The Taiho Code was established in 701, and proclaimed in the following year.
The Taiho Code was established in 701, and proclaimed in the following year.

sen.j: また混乱していた冠位十二階を改め、新たに官位制を設けた。
sen.e: Kan I junikai (twelve grades of cap rank) which had caused confusion, was revised and a new official ranking system was established.
The confusing Kani juni-kai (twelve grades of cap rank) system was revised and a new official ranking system was established.
The confusing Kani juni-kai (twelve grades of cap rank) system was revised and a new official ranking system was established.

sen.j: 今まで散発的にしか記録されていない元号制度の形が整うのもこの大宝年間である。
sen.e: The era name system, which was only recorded sporadically until this point, was put in place during this Taiho era. (during 701-704)
It was during the Taiho era (701-704) when the era system, which had only been recorded sporadically until that point, was put into place.
It was during the Taiho era (701-704) when the era system, which had only been recorded sporadically until that point, was put into place.

sen.j: 檜隈安古岡上陵（ひのくまのあこのうえのみささぎ）に葬られた。
sen.e: The Emperor was entombed in Hi-no Kuma-no Akonoue- no Misasagi.
Emperor Monmu was entombed in the Hi-no kuma-no akonoue-no misasagi Mausoleum.
Emperor Monmu was entombed in the Hi-no kuma-no akonoue-no misasagi Mausoleum.

sen.j: 現在は宮内庁により奈良県明日香村栗原にある栗原塚穴古墳が陵墓に指定されているが、八角墳であり横口式石槨を持つ同村平田の中尾山古墳を真の文武天皇陵とする意見が有力である。
sen.e: As present, Kurihara tsukaana-kofun Tumulus in Kurihara, Asuka Village, Nara Prefecture, is designated as his Imperial Mausoleum by the Imperial Household Agency but there is a stronger view that claims Nakao yama -kofun Tumulus in Hirata, of the same village, which is a Hakkaku-fun (octagonal) Tulumus with Yokoguchi-shiki Sekkaku (stone sarcophagus with a side entrance) as Emperor Monmu's real mausoleum.

At present, Kurihara tsukaana-kofun Tumulus in Kurihara, Asuka-mura Village, Nara Prefecture is designated as his mausoleum by the Imperial Household Agency, but a leading hypothesis today claims that Nakaoyama-kofun Tumulus at Hirata in the same village, which is an octagonal tumulus including a stone chamber with a side entrance, as the Emperor Monmu's genuine mausoleum.
